front.title: Evaluating Congestion Control for Interactive Real-time Media

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The terminology defined in RTP, RTP Profile for Audio and Video Conferences with Minimal Control, RTCP Extended Report (XR), Extended RTP Profile for RTCP-based Feedback (RTP/AVPF) and Support for Reduced-Size RTCP apply.

section.title: Network Scenarios
section.t: this section defines different types of networks where real.-time communication takes places.

section.title: Testcase Definition Structure
Variable Available Bandwidth
section.t:
In the test case the end to end path bandwidth varies overtime between the communicating peers. This test is designed to measure the reactiveness and convergence ability of the candidate algorithm. The test tries to address the requirement number 1{a sub set of the requirements} depicted in [rmcat-req-draft] which requires the algorithm to adapt the flow(s) and provide lower end to end latency when there exists- intermediated bottleneck
change of bandwidth due to interface change and/or routing change and/or intra technology change
persistent network load due to competing traffic It should be noted that the exact impact of change of bandwidth due to any of the above completely depends of under laying network technology used, access types involved, behavior of other traffic on the link and more. There can be enormous amount configuration and combination those need to be addressed. Hence, we describe this test case with a set of know factors those can be extended to device a particular test case.

The expected behavior adaptation algorithm should detect the variation and adapt the flow accordingly. Flow(s) reaches to their maximum, bottleneck appears in the link, flow(s) adapts to the available bandwidth by decreasing it’s bitrate, flow(s) reaches to its maximum when congestion is removed/gone.

To evaluate the performance of the candidate algorithms it is expected to log enough information to visualize the following metics Flow level End to end delay
End to end loss
Transport level Bandwidth utilization
Queue length (ms) average over the length of the session
95 percentile
5 percentile
Example Testbed description:

list.t:
Transport Path direction: Forward, Reverse
Number of bottlenecks : One
Bottleneck link speed : 2Mbps
One-Way propagation delay: 100ms
Maximum end to end jitter: 30ms
Bottleneck queue type: Drop tail
Bottleneck size: 300ms
Bottleneck link loss ratio: 0%

Application Media Source Media direction: Forward
Number of encoder instants/ media sources: two (2)
Encoder configuration: Maximum Bitrate: 2Mpbs
Minimum Bitrate: 200Kbps
Bitrate generation: Variable bitrate
Variation from target bitrate: 5%
Slagishness in bitrate change request: 60ms
Media content: Foreman sequence
Appearace preferece: all at the start up
media startup behaviour: slow start
Competing traffic Number of sources : Zero (0)

Test specific setup Number of bandwidth variation: Two (2)
Link vairation pattern: Sequence number: 1
Amount of change: 50% of bottleneck link speed
Duration: 5s
starttime: 10s
end behaviour: bandwith is restored to the 80% of bottleneck link speed
Link vairation pattern: Sequence number: 2
Amount of change: 50% of bottleneck link speed
Duration: 10s
starttime: 30s
end behaviour: bandwith is restored to the 100% of bottleneck link speed

section.title: Applications Maximum Bitrate is Greater than link capacity
section.t: In this test the application's maximum bitrate is greater than the link available capacity. The application will trieve to reach its maximum bitrate ever as the link capacity does not allow such a demand the congestion control algorithm should come into play and stabilize the applicaiton seding bitrate. This situaltion can arise when a endpoint is connected to another endpoint via a communication link which has a very low bandwidth to offer even if the access network advertized to have more capacity in the link or in a shared channel where network resources has been reserved for other traffic for whatever reason. The test case address the requirement 1 and requrement 10 of the [rmcat-req-draft].

In this test case the algorithm must be able to detect the link capacity constrains and adapt the flow to avoid unwanted oscillation. Flow(s) tries to reach their maximum, link capacity is less than flow(s) maximum requirements, flow (s) adapts and converge the bitrate to the available bandwidth.

To evaluate the performance of the candidate algorithms it is expected to log enough information to visualize the following metics Flow level End to end delay
End to end loss
Bitrate Oscillation
Convergence period.
Transport level Bandwidth utilization
Queue length (ms) average over the length of the session
95 percentile
5 percentile
Example testbed description:

list.t:
Transport Number of bottlenecks : One
Bottleneck link speed : 1Mbps
One-Way propagation delay: 100Ms
Bottleneck queue type: {Drop tail, fq-codel, pie}
Bottleneck size: 300ms
Bottleneck link loss ratio: 0%

Application Media Source Number of encoder instants/ media sources: one (1)
Encoder configuration: Variable bitrate with 5% deviation from tager bitrate
Media content: foreman sequence
Appearace preferece: at the startup
media startup behaviour: {slow start, at max bitrate}
Competing traffic Number of sources : Zero (0)
Source types: Not requred
Adaptation algorithms: Not required

section.title: Flow Competition from Same Adaptive Flow
section.t: In this test case the bottleneck link is shared by more than one real-time interactive flow having the same adaptive mechanism. This is a typical scenario where a real-time interactive application have more than one real-time interactive flows to send to the same desitination and the flows are multiplexed over same port. In such a scenario it is likely that the flows will be routed via same physical path and will have to share the available bandwidth of the path among themselves. For the sake of simplicity it is assumed that there are no other competing taffic souce in the bottleneck link and that the total amount needed to bandwidth needed to accomoded all the real-time interactive flows is greater than the bottleneck link capacity. One can see this is a variation of test case 5.2 however it is a separate test case because the goal of the test is to evaluate the interaction and sharing tendency of the candidate adaptation algorithm where test case 5.2 focuses more on stability. Amoung other this test case particularly addresses the requirement number (2,3 and 10).

It is expected that the competing flows will converge to an optimum bitrate to accomodate all the flows with minumum possible latency and loss. This test will include three flows each appearing at a different period of time. When the second flow appears there should be still available bandwith to accomodate the new flow in the link. However the third flow appears the link bandwidth should be saturated.

To evaluate the performance of the candidate algorithms it is expected to log enough information to visualize the following metics Test duration: 40s
Transport Path direction: Forward, Reverse
Number of bottlenecks: one
Bottleneck link speed: 2.5Mbps
One-Way propagation delay: 50ms
Maximum end to end jitter: 30ms
Bottleneck queue type: droptail
Bottleneck queue size in miliseconds:250ms
Bottleneck link loss ratio: 0.0%
Application: Media Source: Media direction: Forward
Number of media sources: Three (3)
Encoder configuration: Maximum Bitrate:2Mbps
Minimum Bitrate:150Kbps
Bitrate generation: Variable bitrate
Variation from target bitrate: 5%
Slagishness in bitrate change request: 60ms
Media content: Foreman video
Appearace preferece: Sequenctial delayed. See test specific setup below.
Startup behaviour: 200Kbps
Competing traffic source : none.
Other test specific setup: Media flow appearance: Flow no: one
Start ime: 0s
Media flow appearance: Flow no: two
Start ime: 10s
Media flow appearance: Flow no: one
Start ime: 25s
